title: Elton John stopped speaking to mother Sheila over David Furnish jibe
text:
Elton John stopped speaking to his mum after she hit out at David Furnish (Picture: Getty Images )

Elton John has revealed why he stopped speaking to his mother for seven years.

The 72-year-old music icon is releasing his official autobiography and in the book, he details his fractured relationship with his mum Sheila.

His biopic Rocketman, starring Taron Egerton as Elton, shed some light on the pair’s difficult relationship and Elton now writers about one time his mum hit out at his husband David Furnish.

In a heated row, Elton claims Sheila referred to David as a ‘f**king thing’ and it was enough to stop him from speaking to her for several years.

The pair had been arguing about Elton’s former PA Bob Halley, after Bob decided to quit.

According to The Mirror, Elton writes: ‘Mum was absolutely livid when she heard Bob had left — they’d always got on well.

Elton writes about his fractured relationship with mum Sheila in new his book (Picture: WireImage)

‘She didn’t want to hear my version of events, and told me that Bob had been more of a son to her than I’d ever been.’

Elton says his mum then took aim at David, telling him: ‘You care more about that f***ing thing you married than your own mother.’

After that exchange, the pair were no longer on speaking terms and Elton didn’t invite his mum to his wedding when he and David married in 2014.

Elton married David in 2014 and the couple have two sons (Picture: Getty Images for EJAF)

Elton got back in touch with his mum when he found out she was ill and says she had no interest in his children – sons Zachary, eight, and Elijah, six.

During one visit he had told his mum he loved her and she replied: ‘I love you too, but I don’t like you at all.’

As well as his family, Elton also touches on surviving prostate cancer in his autobiography and his experiences with the Royal family – including one time he says he saw the Queen ‘slap’ her nephew.

The Crocodile Rock hit-maker is also set to star in a BBC special, presented by Graham Norton, and it’s been described as his most ‘uncensored interview to date’.

Speaking about the special, Elton said: ‘The past two years have felt truly monumental for me, and with the release of Rocketman, the Farewell Yellow Brick Road tour and my autobiography coming up, it felt like the perfect opportunity to reflect on it all with Graham.’

Elton John: Uncensored will look back over his 50 year career in the music industry, his childhood as Reginald Dwight, his battle with addiction and how fatherhood has positively impacted on his life.

Sir Elton John’s official autobiography, Me: Elton John, is set for release on 15 October.
